title: Urgent recall of tens of thousands of Volkswagen, Audi and Skoda cars due to a dangerous fault
text:
14,000 Audi A1, Audi A3 and Audi TT models are also affected by the recall

4,500 Skodas are also at risk of the fault, including Fabia, Rapid, Octavia

Around 62,000 Volkswagen vehicles are affected including Golf, Beetle and Polo

Dual-clutch transmissions called 'DSG' could suffer an 'interruption of power'

Urgent recall has been issued for 80,000 Audi, Volkswagen and Skoda vehicles

An urgent recall has been issued for 80,000 Audi, Volkswagen and Skoda vehicles built between 2008 and 2015.

Around 62,000 Volkswagen Golf, Beetle, Polo, Jetta, Passat and Caddy models are affected, as well as 4,500 Skoda Fabia, Rapid, Octavia, Yeti and Superb.

The recall is also issued to 14,000 Audi A1 (2011 to 2016 models), Audi A3 (2008 to 2016 models) and Audi TT (2012 to 2016 models).

According to Volkswagen Australia, dual-clutch transmissions marketed as 'DSG' could suffer an 'interruption of power'.

The company said that due to incorrect manufacturing, this could result in a loss of oil pressure in the hydraulic system of the gearbox followed by an interruption of power.

Around 62,000 Volkswagen vehicles are affected, including Golf (pictured), Beetle, Polo, Jetta, Passat and Caddy models

This could lead the vehicle to go into 'limp' mode, and after being turned off the car cannot be restarted unless looked at by a qualified Volkswagen technician.

Volkswagen said around 23,000 cars may be affected by the problem, but the manufacturer wants to check a further 40,000 cars to be safe.

Volkswagen Australia executive Jason Bradshaw said vehicles need to be physically examined to determine whether they are faulty or not.

'While we know 23,000 vehicles may have this incorrectly manufactured component, we cannot be certain of identifying these by Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) alone,' he said.

'We want to physically examine them and those [additional vehicles] with a potentially faulty component can have it replaced.'

Customers will be contacted in the coming weeks and invited to bring their cars in for inspection or undergo repair work free of charge.
description: Around 62,000 Volkswagen vehicles are affected, including Golf, Beetle, Polo, Jetta, Passat and Caddy models.
authors: Alana Mazzoni For Daily Mail Australia
